title: Stepping Out of the Protective Bubble: Recovery From Opioid Addiction

content: When I was struggling with opioid addiction , I often thought about how much easier my life would be if I were free from it. I saw getting clean as the end goal – something that if I could just achieve, everything would be OK again.

I held on to that expectation throughout my journey to sobriety, through all the nights of wanting to give up and take a pill to make the pain go away, and through all the moments of pain along the way.
And yes, when I reached that day where I was finally clean and didn’t have a trace of opioids in my body, it was a huge relief. But much to my surprise, everything was not simply OK again.

I was finally free of the iron grip opioids had held me in, but I was also broken. Defeated. Left feeling as if I’d lost my chance in life and would just need to settle for whatever came my way from then on.

content: So, I continued living my life. I did things I’d always known I would do: I got married, had kids, and tried my best to support my family. But as far as my progression went, I was done. I’d had my chance and I made a mess of it. I wasn’t going to go through that again.

For 8 years, I stayed in the protective bubble I built around myself. I lived my life, but I didn’t put myself out there. I stayed in my comfort zone, too defeated and afraid to try for something more.

It was as if my life was in a kind of suspended animation. Much of the day, I would simply go through the motions, feeling sad to be retired from life in my late 20s, but not knowing how to change it. I didn’t want to risk anything, especially not the family I’d always wanted, but I wasn’t happy living this way.

Many nights were spent on my knees, begging the heavens for help. I wanted to change, but I was so afraid to leave my bubble. It was safe there; it was known . I didn’t want to risk losing that sense of security.

content: Ironically, my family was what drove me to change. Children, even at a very young age, are much more perceptive than we often give them credit for. My daughters could see my unhappiness, and it wasn’t until I began to see how it was affecting them that I finally got the courage to make some changes.

I started small, much like taking a few steps at a time. I started writing again and even shared my experiences with a few people. I started applying for jobs, even without that college degree I thought I’d lost my chance to get.
I started taking risks. Taking chances. Putting myself out there in situations where I wasn’t sure about the outcome, but trying, nonetheless.

I finally realized that in order to fully recover from my addiction and no longer let it control me, I had to break out of the protective bubble I’d built around myself. I had to get past my own personal comfort zone because without doing that, there was no way for me to grow.

content: Life is in full color for me now. I’ve found more joy and fulfillment than I ever thought was possible. I’ve come to the realization that opioid addiction didn’t make me who I am – it was just a small part of my life.
Something that’s shaped me into the person I am today.
Those 8 years spent living in my protective bubble were muted, both in color and in progress. I was stagnant, afraid to seek out more for myself because I didn’t want to lose what I already had.
Turns out, there are endless opportunities for us all, no matter where we may have once been.
